description: From Middle English schambyll, shamyll, schamel, from Old English sċeamol, scamol (“bench, stool”), from Proto-West Germanic *skamul, *skamil, from Proto-Germanic *skamulaz, *skamilaz, from Latin scamellum, a variant of scabellum (“footstool”). Cognate with Dutch schemel (“footstool, bench”), German Schemel (“stool”), Danish skammel (“stool”). Icelandic skemill (“footstool”).

entries.meaning: (mining) One of a succession of niches or platforms, one above another, to hold ore which is thrown successively from platform to platform, and thus raised to a higher level.

verbs.description: shamble (third-person singular simple present shambles, present participle shambling, simple past and past participle shambled)

entries.meaning: To walk while shuffling or dragging the feet.
examples: I wasn't too impressed with the fellow, when he shambled in unenthusiastically and an hour late.
